The one wants Braines; the second Ʋtterance, the third wants Strength; No woonder if the Auditors wanted Eares: and the best I can say of them is, Here they came in, and here they went out again; Yet I cannot but say, that one of them well deserves to be the Parliament Oratour, so M. Lisle begins, My Lord Major, and you worthy Gentlemen of the famous City of London: I am commanded, &c. They commanded him to flatter them; and he does it to the purpose; For famous they are, and will be to many Generations in that acception, Fama est malum: Rebellion is an evill thing: Another of them will deserve to be the City Remembrancer, and M. Tate challenges it at his very entrance; but I must remember him, Mendacem memorem esse oportet; But poore man, he will forget both, to lye, or to remember to lye, when the end of his speech hath taken effect; The Popish Party will kill you all: The third will deserve to be the City Iudge; For in his beginning he arraignes the King and Queene, both with joy and sorrow, only he forbeares to give sentence, for his last words are, I need not repeat the words: Not shall I need to satisfie you in these Letters: Doe but read that excellently worked Instrument, called, A Key to the King's Cabinet, and that other, A Letter upon the Annotations &c. And if you have not the Head of M. Lisle, the Heart of M. Tate, or the Feet of M. Browne, I dare say, you will no longer be either Rebel, or Puritan.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: Sir, I pray use not those words any more to me: I confesse I am silenced for any more Replyes against you, or for Defence of this Rebellion; For lesse I perceive it is not, and I would to God it were a lesse Rebellion then I perceive it is; That I Perish not in it, Here, and now before God and the World I protest my unfaigned sorrow, that ever I had a hand in this Accursed Rebellion, or ever contributed Monye, or desire towards it, and beseech God and the King to pardon Me, and you and all good Men to pray for me, and wish with all my Soule, that those Fatall dayes to King CHARLES, October 1643. at Horne-Castle in Lincolneshire, Iuly, 1644. at Marstone-moore in Yorkeshire, and Iune 27. 1645. at Nasby, may never come into any Kalendar or Almanack of Remembrance, least it prove an Encouragement to another Rebellion.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Enough Sir, I thank God for his Grace in you, I thank you for testifying so much to the World, but let those Dayes be remembred in the mourning Letters of Griefe and Sorrow, because our sinnes were so great, as to provoke God to permit such Clouds to frowne so much upon his Annointed: And let these Fatall Dayes to the Rebels, be registred in the Dominicall letters of Ioy and Gladnesse, in this or the like manner.

We doe and will give thankes to thee, O Lord, with our whole hearts, Ps. 111.1. secretly among the Faithfull, and publickly in the Congregation, because thou hast done such a marvellous worke, v. 4. v. 6. v. 9. as to shew thy People the power of thy workes, and given us a hope of Redemption by a glorious Victory over the Rebels at Wickfield, Sept. 23. 1642.

We doe give thanks to thee, O Lord, Ps. 118.1. and confesse that thou art gratious, because thou hast taken part with thine Annointed, and them that help Him, against the desire of his Enemies at Edgehill, Octo. 23. 1642.

We give thanks to thee the God of all Gods, Ps. 136.1. we give thanks to thee the Lord of all Lords, because thou hast continued thy mercy to thine Annointed, and by a mighty Hand, and a stretched out Arme, v. 2. v. 12. v. 15. hast overthrowne Pharaoh and his Host in the Thames, neare Brainceford, Novemb. 12, & 13. 1642.

Blessed be thou, O Lord, our Soveraignes strength, and our owne, Ps. 144.1. who hast taught our Hands to Warre, and our Fingers to Fight; our Hope, our Castle, and Deliverer, our Defender in whom we trust, which hast subdued the People under him, and given Him a glorious Victory over his Rebellious Subjects at Cyrencester, Febr. 2. 1642.

We magnifie thee, O God our King, Ps. 145.1. v. 2. v. 6. and will praise thy Name for ever and ever: Every day will we give thankes to thee, and praise thy Name for ever and ever: We will speake of the might of thy marvellous acts, and tell of thy greatnesse; v. 7. v. 8. We will remember thine abundant kindnesse, and sing of thy righteousnesse, because thou hast been gracious and mercifull, and of great goodnesse, in upholding our Soveraigne who was falling, and lifted up Him thy Servant who was downe, v. 14. by a glorious Victory at Stratton in Devonshire, May, 16. 1643.

Our Soule shall praise thee while we live, yea, Ps. 146.1. v. 6. as long as we have any being, we will sing praises unto thee, because thou hast helped him to right who suffered wrong, in Conquering him who was called the Conqueror, and given the King a glorious Victory over him at Roundway-downe, Iuly, 13: 1643.

None of these thy mercies, nor any other shall goe out of our remembrance, we will never cease praising of thee for thy mercies past, nor praying unto thee for thy mercies future; which we beseech thee to multiply upon the Head of our King, and in the Heart of His Kingdomes, untill thou hast subdued all Rebels, and reduced all Cities and Citizens, all Townes and Subjects to the Duty of Loyalty, and the happinesse of Peace, through Jesus Christ. Amen.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I perceive you have done, and I confesse you have well done; for hereby you have cleared our Religion from any aspersion of this Rebellion.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Not so, for before we part, It will appeare that you are more guilty in the Genus of Rebellion, then the Puritans, and as guilty in the Species of this Rebellion, as the Puritan; for you were the first Founders of this Doctrine, They but your Followers, and so made your sinne in Doctrine, their owne in Practice: They were the first Projectors and Actors in this Rebellion, and you their Followers: & so you have made their sin of Action your own by Imitation.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: You will hardly make this good.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Trye, and let the Issue prove it.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: First, then I say, That the first Rebellion you can charge upon us, the Papists, was that in 1605. which was but in Agitation neither, never in Execution; I meane the Powder plot; but we can charge many upon the Puritans, long before that time: Namely in Scotland, all the time of King James, and a great part of his Mothers Raigne, Q. Mary, and long before that in Germany.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Well, as high as you goe, you are still their Predecessors; For the greatest Antiquity of guilt in this kind, either for Doctrine or Practice, that you can charge upon the Puritans, is either in the time of Mr. Calvin, or a little before him, in the time of Dr Luther, who did what he could to quench that Fire: but long before both these, it was continued in point of Doctrine by the Clergie-Iesuits, and conceived into the point of practice by the Lay-Iesuits.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Never tell me of Iesuits, for I tell you once more, I am not Iesuited: so farre I beleeve King James, where he saies, That Jesuitae nihil aliud sunt quàm Puritano-Papistae, Iesuits are nothing but Puritan-Papists, I conceive I shall do no wrong to speake it in words at length, and not in Figures, The Brittaine-Puritans, are Roman-Jesuits, and the Roman-Jesuits, are Brittaine-Puritans: but we that are only Papists, have nothing to doe with either.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p:
I would you had not: But you are called Papistae à Papa; Papists
from the Pope; and the Popes Doctrines Ex Cathedrâ especially you are bound to obey. And a Papall doctrine it is, That Subjects may be discharged and absolved from their Oaths of Alleagiance, in some cases, and being so absolved, may beare Armes against their Soveraigne.

If you will not believe these words, look upon that Impious Bull of that Pope Pius against Queen Elizabeth, and look a good deale higher, that you may not take me tripping; upon Greg. 7. whom I named before; And that you may be sure this Doctrine is not yet forgotten, or came under any Index Expurgatorius, Bellarmines own books were Licensed by your last Pope, and the best you had these Hundred years: I believe too there were other Papists then Jesuited in the Irish Rebellion.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Alas, Alas Sir, you know the Irish lands were all sold, and themselves threatned to be all slaves or killed; And will not a Beare bite it any comes to take away his skinn before he be destroyed; you know the Irish had Agents waiting at Westminster, and in that Kingdomes name promising all due obedience to the Lawes of this Kingdome, if they might enjoy those Fortunes which God and Nature had given them: you know that Scotland led them the way; and why should not they expect as good successe? and for ought I know, it cannot be tearmed a Rebellion against the King, but against Rebels in defending of themselves.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: I know what you say, I know and wish that I could say with you For ought I know, it cannot be tearmed a Rebellion against the King: But I know it was: They might lawfully have defended themselves against Rebels, and been good Subjects; but when they came to offend the King, they made themselves Rebels: and which of the Rebels, the Papists there, or the Puritans here, have been most Barbarous, it will require an abler tongue then mine to determine; But thus much I will say —

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Pray Sir, speak no more of it; I confesse it to the shame of the Roman Catholicks there, and here, and over all the World besides: But it comforts me to remember, how suddenly they have laid down their Armes; even as soon as ever the King eased them of some grievances; And to wipt away their own transgressions in Ireland, they have promised to assist the King with Meanes and Men, to quench this Rebellion in England.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Since you are so desirous to have it husht (though it be very soule, and will be hit in their Teeth hereafter) I will forbeare; only let me aske you one question; If the Irish Papists having once atchieved their own ends, shall neglect to performe all their Promises and Engagements hereafter, what will you then think of Poperie?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Why doe you aske such an uncharitable question? It is farced with too much jealousie; can you think them men void of such common honesty, as after the receipt of so many unparallelld Acts of Grace, from such a mercifull and sweet natur'd King, who is as ready to give, as His Subjects can be to aske, and readier to forgive, then Rebels will be to repent, to be so gracelesse? If you acquit not your selfe fairely, I shall think the worse of you and your Religion so long as I live.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: I Prophecy not; I pray God I be no Prophet in my conceipts; and I pray God they prove this last question of mine to proceed from a misgrounded Jealousie, and not a well grounded feare. For in truth I feare, yes, and believe it too, Papists are as well versed in Nulla fides cum Haereticis, as, In aliquibus casibus Reges licet dejicere; No promise to be kept with Hereticks, as, it is lawfull in some cases to resist Kings.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Why, is this a Popish tenent too.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: I shall not believe it if the Irish keep touch.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: Whether they doe or no, a Popish tenent it is; and thus I prove it.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: You shall not need; but are you Hereticks?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: No, we are by our Proper name Christians, and by our Appellative, or Sir-name, Catholicks: the Papists call us Hereticks: and if we were what they call us, yet, that Tenent never came from St Peter, nor is to be maintained amongst Christians; The very Turks abhorre it; and therefore I ask you again, what you will think of Popery, if the Irish Rebels doe neglect the performance of their promises.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Why then I will think as ill of Papists, as now I think of Puritans; and promise you upon the credit of an Honest man, to turne Protestant.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.p: Thankes to Heaven; thankes to you; I thanke you heartily; and God send us all an union both in opinion and affection.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: AMEN.
